awd_titl_txt: Regulatory mechanisms of plant heterotrimeric G-protein signaling
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants respond to a variety of internal cues and external signals by employing multiple protein signaling complexes, which facilitate changes in plant physiology and environmental adaptation to optimize growth and development. Heterotrimeric GTP-binding proteins (G-proteins) are a class of proteins that have emerged as key regulators of a multitude of plant signaling pathways. These proteins are currently a focus of intense research due to their involvement in modulation of many agronomically important traits such as seed yield, plant defense responses, symbiosis and nitrogen use efficiency. The mechanistic details of how a small number of proteins regulate a multitude of signaling processes remain largely unknown. This research focuses on the regulatory mechanisms of G-proteins and will address some of the unique features of plant G-protein signaling, which remain undiscovered to date. Successful completion of this research will not only fill major gaps in our knowledge of plant G-protein signaling mechanisms, but will also build a foundation for further targeted studies in other economically important plants, where detailed mechanistic studies are currently not possible. Therefore, in addition to advancing the basic understanding in the field, this study may also apply broadly to some of the problems that challenge the world today, such as generating higher yield with limited resources and unfavorable environments. The work will involve training of a technician and a postdoctoral scientist in multidisciplinary approaches, as well as mentoring of undergraduate students. The research will also help promote an understanding of plant science to high school students and the general public via a series of hands on experiments and interactive presentations.

Naturally occurring or engineered changes in the level of G-proteins cause profound effects on plant architecture, abiotic stress responses and yield potential, making elucidation of their underlying signaling mechanisms a high priority. The principal investigator has shown that the regulator of G-protein signaling (RGS) protein and a phospholipase D (PLDalpha1) protein act in a double negative loop to precisely control the level of active G-alpha protein in plant cells. The research will now focus on predicting and validating specific G-protein regulatory circuits using biochemical modeling and mutant response assays. Evaluation of the ancestral versus derived states of the G-protein regulatory modes will also be investigated by comparative evolutionary and genetic analyses.  This research seeks to answer important questions related to plant G-protein regulatory mechanisms such as, (i)  how is the plant G-protein cycle regulated, especially in the context of its unusual biochemical properties? (ii) how is the specificity of response regulation achieved despite a paucity of core components? (iii) how the activation/deactivation balance of G-alpha protein cycle is controlled in the absence of canonical G-Protein-Coupled Receptors in plants? (iv) why is the loss of a key regulatory protein (e.g. RGS protein) tolerated in a subset of plant species, even though it acts as an important regulator of the G-protein cycle in plants that possess it? and (v) what might replace RGS protein function in plants that lack it? Successful completion of this research is expected to not only shed light on G-protein signaling in plants, but to uncover additional, perhaps novel signaling and regulatory pathways in other eukaryotes that have been obscured until now due to the complexity of interactions.

por.por_cntn:
All living organisms interact with and respond to their surrounding environment. A the cellular level, these interactions are mediated by proteins that sense the environmental signals (sensor or receptor proteins) and then change in such a way that the information is transmitted to the effectors proteins, that respond to these signals. A central premise of biological research is to identify such proteins, determine how they transmit the signals and what are their effects. One such class of proteins, found in organisms as diverse as fungi, algae, worms, flies, humans and plants, is the heterotrimeric G-protein signaling complex. As the name suggests, the proteins are comprised of three (trimeric) distinct (hetero) subunits, Gα, Gβ and Gγ and they connect signal perception at the plasma membrane by sensory or receptor protein to effectors inside the cells. Even though the core constituents of G-proteins are similar in all organisms, how these interact with the receptor and effector proteins is different in plants compared to other organisms.  Plants have some unique regulators and effectors of G-proteins and their mechanistic details remain unclear.   As G-proteins affect key agronomic traits and plant survival, comprehensive knowledge of these mechanisms is crucial for their future application. The overarching goal of this research was to define the novel G-protein signaling mechanisms in a broader evolutionary context with the following specific aims:

Aim 1. Prediction and validation of specific G-protein regulatory circuits using biochemical modeling and specific biological response assays 

Aim 2. Evaluation of the ancestral versus derived states of the G-protein regulatory modes by comparative evolutionary and genetic analyses 

Outcomes-Intellectual Merit: With the research supported by this funding, we confirmed the hypothesis that proteins other than the classical regulatory RGS protein can acts as GAPs (GTPase activity accelerating proteins) of Gα proteins, in plants. We also showed that although plants have lost RGS proteins many time during evolution, when they are present, they are functional. We also identified genes co-regulated by Gα and RGS proteins, and several downstream effectors, that will be evaluated in the future. Finally, we uncovered that there is a distinction in the G-protein signaling mechanisms when comparing the short-term stress responses with longer-term developmental responses. Any Gα protein is capable of regulating the response to stress in Arabidopsis (a model plant), but only higher plant ones can also affect development.  Overall this research established the novelty of plant G-protein signaling mechanisms and uncovered fascinating new areas for future research. This research also resulted in publication of over 15 peer reviewer journal articles.

Outcomes-Broader Impacts: This funding provided training to four post-doctoral scientists, three of which are woman and POC. They were provided with multiple training opportunities, including cross-disciplinary state-of-the-art research, and in responsible conduct of research, science communication (oral and written), professional development and acquiring soft-skill. The post-docs mentored technicians, high school student and undergraduate students. The results of this research were disseminated by the PI and the post docs in multiple presentations at various local, national and international conferences.

Summary: This research funding has generated a knowledgebase useful for elucidating G-protein signaling mechanisms in plants. It has also generated new resources and opened up novel areas for future research. Finally, given the roles of G-proteins in affecting environmental stress responses and in yield, the findings form this research have the potential to affect future agriculture.
